name: Ascetic Grandmaster

actions.name: Unarmed Strike
actions.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit  reach 5 ft.  one target. Hit: 10 (1d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage.

reactions.name: Deft Dodge (1/Round)
reactions.desc: When an attacker that the grandmaster can see hits them with an attack, the grandmaster halves the attacks damage against them.

reactions.name: Ascetic grandmasters lead the finest monasteries in the world or travel alone seeking worthy challenges and students
reactions.desc: They often appear unassuming, but challenging the speed and strength of these legendary martial artists is akin to challenging a hurricane.

reactions.name: Trained Dash
reactions.desc: The grandmaster takes the Dash action.

special_abilities.name: Athlete
special_abilities.desc: The grandmaster only uses 5 feet of movement when standing from prone and can make a running jump after moving only 5 feet rather than 10.

special_abilities.name: Evasion
special_abilities.desc: When the grandmaster makes a Dexterity saving throw against an effect that deals half damage on a success, they take no damage on a success and half damage on a failure.

special_abilities.name: Magic Resistance
special_abilities.desc: The grandmaster has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

special_abilities.name: Mobile
special_abilities.desc: After the grandmaster makes a melee attack against a creature on their turn, until the end of their turn they do not provoke opportunity attacks from that creature.

special_abilities.name: Reactive
special_abilities.desc: The grandmaster can take a reaction on each creatures turn.

special_abilities.name: Stunning Strike (1/Turn)
special_abilities.desc: When the grandmaster hits a creature with a melee attack, they can force it to make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, it is stunned until the end of the grandmasters next turn.

special_abilities.name: Unarmored Defense
special_abilities.desc: The grandmasters AC equals 10 + their Dexterity modifier + their Wisdom modifier.
